newsitem.title: CANADA: CANADA NEW HOUSING PRICE INDEX RISES IN JUNE.
newsitem.headline: CANADA NEW HOUSING PRICE INDEX RISES IN JUNE.

text.p: Canada's new housing price index rose 1.0 percent in June to 132.9 (base 1986) from June 1996, Statistics Canada said on Tuesday.
Index June yr pct month pct
The index measures changes of contractors' selling prices of new residential houses.
Statistics Canada said this was the fourth consecutive
month for a year-over-year increase, after 31 consecutive decreases between July 1994 and January 1997.
The agency said the general improvement in housing markets recently is linked to stronger consumer confidence and favorable interest rates.

The New Housing Price Index increased by 1.0% in June compared with the same period a year earlier. This is the fourth consecutive month for which the index has registered an annual increase, after 31 consecutive decreases between July 1994 and January 1997.
From May to June 1997, the index increased 0.1%, an eighth consecutive monthly increase.

The general improvement in housing markets in recent months has been attributable to higher consumer confidence and favourable interest rates. Despite the general optimism, the competitive nature of housing markets coupled with regional concerns has moderated price increases or caused decreases in some of the cities surveyed. Nevertheless, the outlook for future housing construction seems encouraging.
Housing construction intentions, as measured by Statistics Canada's building permits data, were up 22.0% for the first six months of 1997 compared with 1996.
According to the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation, housing starts were up 26.9% for the first half of 1997 compared with the same time period in 1996.
The Canadian Real Estate Association reported that this year's first-half resale transactions were up 17.9% from the same period last year.
On April 1, 1997, the Harmonized Sales Tax (HST) came

into effect in Newfoundland, Nova Scotia and New Brunswick. In April, the New Housing Price Index, which is a contractors' selling price index, showed monthly declines in all cities that are surveyed in these provinces. It would appear that some sample builders have not yet fully reflected the impact of the HST on the prices of new houses. Available on CANSIM: matrix 2032.
